speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument this morning in Case 14-275, Horne v. Department of Agriculture. Mr. McConnell.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that -- I thought the growers were paid only for the volume that they were permitted, that was permitted, the permitted volume, and that they were not paid for what is -- goes in the reserve pool.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are you objecting to the volume limitation, or is it just that the -- the reserve pool that you find -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- troublesome?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that's what so -- so puzzling because if -- if you're not challenging the volume limit itself, you can't sell more than 60 percent of your crop.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And what happens to the rest of it?  You're not going to be able to feed your family on the rest, the 40 percent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But if it wasn't, if -- Alderson Reporting Company if we just had a volume, you cannot sell more than X amount, then I take it that the grower would get nothing, nothing at all.  At least with this reserve pool, there is the possibility of getting some money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So what you're complaining about is the administrative expenses? I don't -- I still don't understand why this makes this a Penn Central case as opposed to a -- a per se taking.  You've -- you've given up on this being a Penn Central case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And so basically, you see a nexus between the regulation and its purpose. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How is this different than Leonard?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Gosh, is that really true, Mr. McConnell?  I mean, when these fishermen took the oysters, the -- you know, including the shells from the bay or other waters, you know, they could then sell the oysters.  Why weren't the oyster shells theirs at that point?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I mean, I guess I -- I would have thought that as soon as they bring the oysters out of the bay and they haul their catch to shore, that what they've hauled to shore is then theirs. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, so I guess what Justice Sotomayor's question is is why wouldn't the same be true as to raisins?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So you think that Leonard is -- is -- is an animals case as opposed to a, you know, the State can tax your property case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's not how it was applied by the court.  They called it a tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But neither did they -- but it didn't happen that way in Leonard, either.  What the Court was basically saying is the government could do this because this is a good in commerce.  As long as it could meet the Penn Central test, that there is some nexus between the government's goal and the -- and the -- and -- and the regulation, then it's okay. Now, there they used it to fertilize oyster ponds or to refertilize the oysters.  Here they're doing it to maintain prices and giving you whatever left -- whatever is left over on the reserve.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Could you tell me where in Leonard that was discussed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought that the -- what the Constitution required for a taking was just compensation, not -- not a reasonable nexus to a -- a Alderson Reporting Company good policy.  Am I -- am I wrong about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I didn't think so.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I -- I suppose that question, underlying the government's briefs in this -- we can ask them what its position is or you can characterize their position if you choose -- is the thing -- since we could do this other ways, what difference does it make?  Do you understand to -- that to be their -- an underlying premise in their argument or -- or is that unfair on my part?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If that's the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If that's your position, why didn't you ask -- you're attacking this reserve Alderson Reporting Company arrangement and the -- the possession -- the government's possession of the raisins themselves.  And you -- as far as I've heard so far, you are not attacking volume limit; you cannot market more than X amount.  Why didn't you then ask the Department of Agriculture for an exemption from the reserve pool? Instead of -- see, what you're trying to do now is to get rid of the volume limit as well.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the part that isn't given to the government, suppose we just -- couldn't you have asked to excise that part of it and still leave the limit on the amount that could be marketed?  I mean, we have a division between what goes in the reserve and what can be marketed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It is your -- is it a -- is it counterclaim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: A defense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If -- if there was a taking, would there be any obligation on your part to propose an alternative to the taking?  The government comes and takes your property.  Can't you just resist the taking without saying, oh, government, you can do this in another way.  Please do it in a different way. You don't have to do that, do you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I didn't think so.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So -- so my question is, it goes on from this.  I mean, maybe the answer is, well, just don't decide that.  But look, I assume with you for the moment for argument's sake, I have some raisins in my Alderson Reporting Company basement.  I'm in this program.  The government comes with a shovel and some burlap sacks; it takes the raisins.  I would say, well, sounds like a taking to me. At the next point --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- the Constitution doesn't forbid takings.  It says what you have to do is pay just compensation.  Now, it's at that point I want to know what happens, because I guess the government could argue, look at this program, it's a big program.  This program, what it does is it gives raisin farmers, at the public's expense, more money.  So if, in fact, you don't want us to take your raisins, all right, fine.  But there'd be no program if everybody said that.  So we have a rule against free riders. Now we'll give you what it cost you to take your raisins.  What it cost you is, in fact, the difference between what you receive given the program and what you would receive without the program.  That difference works in your favor.  It gives you money.  It doesn't take money.  So there is no compensation due. In fact, if we were to have compensation, you should pay us, the government. So how are you going to get by that part? And if you can't get by that part, how are you going to Alderson Reporting Company avoid paying the fine? See, I don't see the relation between the taking argument, which is maybe all we have to decide, and how eventually you either get some money or you don't have to pay the fine.  If you have a minute, I'd appreciate just the explanation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I don't want to interrupt you, because you're going to get to the theoretical argument in a moment.  But wouldn't -- isn't the response to that, well, the price that you just quoted Alderson Reporting Company is because of this program, and that's circular, or am I wrong about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Except weren't we told that the demand for raisins is inelastic?  So if you glut the market, you're going to have what happened before the RCA.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You're going to have prices dropping.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's the -- that's the purpose of free competition, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, that's today, but you haven't paid a reserve in years now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So one of your arguments could be -- I get your argument now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Exactly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  So what we should say, in your view, do you have any objection to my writing, if I were to write it, like this, taking. Yeah, it's a taking.  Okay.  But the Constitution forbids takings without compensation.  The object of the program is, at least in general, to give farmers more compensation than they would have without it.  Programs can work badly, sometimes they're counterproductive, but if this is working well, that's what happens. Alderson Reporting Company So we send it back to the court to see, did the program work well? Did it work to actually make your -- your client better off? What rules do we follow? That's how we should do this, in your opinion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry, it was --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Can I take you back, Mr. McConnell, to the -- whether it is a taking point? And I've -- I've just been trying to think about whether your argument would apply to other kinds of programs and how it might apply to other kinds of programs. So how about just programs where the government says, give us -- produce records for us. I'm sure that there are a lot of programs like that in the world. And there is something intuitive about your saying, well, the government is asking us to turn over stuff. And I'm wondering, it seems to me that the government asks people to turn over stuff all the time Alderson Reporting Company in the form of records.  How would that fare under your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I don't know if they're historical --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I don't know if they're historical value.  They're just physical objects, in the same way the raisins are physical objects.  And the government wants some records.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: No, but -- so you're saying that the government couldn't ask you to deliver records to them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: They're just keeping the records.  They're keeping the records.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I guess I just don't understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, there -- there are cases on custodial -- government all the time in criminal cases takes control of valuable objects for evidence, and sometimes it keeps it forever and ever. And in those cases, I think there is a taking if it's too long, I think we've said that.  Or I think other courts have said that.  In other words --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- the government can keep it only so long as it's reasonably necessary for the case.  You have a valuable diamond ring which Alderson Reporting Company is evidence and the government keeps it, but it keeps it only for so long as it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, I'm trying to understand why --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I guess I'm trying to understand why it's far afield, and what it's far afield from. I mean, you even said, well, information is no problem. But people have property interests in information all the time, and if the government says you have to give us that information, which counts as property, why is that not subject to your rule?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So how about the Alderson Reporting Company Monsanto case, where we said the turning over of trade secrets, which is property, you've just admitted that, for the privilege of selling other commodities, the pesticides, was okay, wasn't a taking.  How do you deal with that case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Getting 63 -- getting $63 more a pound for what you sell seems like a significant benefit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But you couldn't do it. Alderson Reporting Company You would have a product that would be valueless except for that which you could eat at home, but you didn't intend to eat it at home because you gave it up for sale.  If they -- if they gave you the raisins, would you be able to export them and get the government subsidy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: My point is just you couldn't otherwise sell this commodity.  If all they did was put it in a house and say to the producers, sell 60 percent this year, what would you do with the raisins?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: They'd just sit there --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, suppose --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the market goes the other way?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- still, the curlicue on this -- I've -- you've helped a lot in my thinking.  But there's still what we do about this fine.  And the reason that I'm -- this may be just a curlicue on the case.  But -- but the way I'm thinking of it, imaginary plan -- I don't think I'll ask it.  I'll figure it out myself.  I'd like you to reserve your time. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Kneedler.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: These plaintiffs are ingrates, right?  You're -- you're -- you're really helping them?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's for their benefit, and -- and -- and they wanted this, didn't they?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You say it's one little feature of an overall program.  That little feature happens to be the taking of raisins.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, you could have a lot of features.  There's no objection to having many features, but where one of them is a taking, you -- you have to justify it by just compensation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You used to say -- you used to say it's not a taking if it involves just personal property, only real estate.  Are you still --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The government has abandoned that position?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Took your raisins, for example?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, the -- the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- the government can -- can prevent you from putting something into the stream of commerce, can charge you for putting something into the stream?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, including taking, Alderson Reporting Company including --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- Including taking?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- it's an unconstitutional condition, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Taking without just compensation would be an unconstitutional condition for putting something into the stream of -- stream of commerce.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Is there any -- is there any limit to that argument?  There are some examples in the briefs that are pretty startling.  Could the government say to a manufacturer of cellphones, you can sell cellphones; however, every fifth one you have to give to us?  Or a manufacturer of cars, you can sell cars in the United States, but every third car you have to give to Alderson Reporting Company the -- to the United States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Why would it be -- why would it be different?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, sure.  This would be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So -- so you -- so you say if the government took all GM's cars, then it would be okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But just not a third?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but just -- before you do, I mean, the -- the rationale -- I mean, the government can come up with a rationale to justify those examples really easily. You say cellphone providers benefit greatly if there's a broader cellphone market, if more people are using them.  So we're going to take every fifth one Alderson Reporting Company and give it to people who might otherwise not be able to afford a cellphone. And that will help cellphone manufacturers , because more and more people will have them. More and more people will want them. Therefore, it's okay. That's the same rationale you're applying here. This is for the good of the people whose property we're taking.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And you can do what you've done in most other marketing orders, which is not take their raisins. Instead, say, look, you can only plant, you know, 63 percent of your acreage this year, or you can only produce, you know, 28 tons. That's how most of them work, and most of the them thereby are, I presume, analyzed under Penn Central. This is different. This is different because you come up with the truck and you get the shovels and you take their raisins, probably in the dark of night. (Laughter.) Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They -- they -- what do you mean, they don't go to the -- does not the government own them?  Do -- do you deny that the government owns them?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How -- how many -- how many -- how much from those sales did -- did these Petitioners acquire in the two years at issue here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How much -- how much money was given back to them?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Zero?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Over the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Sorry.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Over the history of the program -- it starts in 1949, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And so in how many years Alderson Reporting Company while the program is in effect was there a distribution to the -- to the growers?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Kneedler, I, too, am troubled, like Justice Alito, about his every fifth telephone or whatever.  Every fifth car or every fifth telephone you have to give to the government.  You -- I don't know you've answered that question.  Is that a taking or isn't it?  And --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- what's the basis to distinguish --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- distinguish it -- it from --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Kneedler, this --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: This -- this is a -- a historical quirk that you have to defend.  You could achieve your -- the government's objectives, just as you do in most other cases, through volume limitations that don't require a physical taking. For whatever reason, in the history of the New Deal, this one was set up differently.  And so we're here dealing with a classical, physical taking.  We are not going to jeopardize the marketing -- the Agriculture Alderson Reporting Company Department's Marketing Order regime. And by the way, it better be the Department of Agriculture that takes these -- you said earlier it's Raisin Committee -- or else you're going to have a lot of trouble in your government speech cases, where you always make the point that these committees are, in fact, the government.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Correct , correct.  So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- therefore, what is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Look -- look.  This is -- I'm having trouble with the same thing.  I agree so far with what the Chief Justice said. Go back to the New Deal.        You can, in fact, burn raisins, the point of which was to have fewer raisins, the result of which was to raise the price of raisins from $100 a pound to -- or a bushel -- to 400. That was thought to make the farmer better off, which it did.  And it made the customers worse off. Alderson Reporting Company Then someone had a good idea and said it's sort of wasteful to burn raisins.  Let's take the raisins we'd otherwise burn and give them to schoolchildren.  And maybe we could even sell a few, and if we do, we'll give that extra money to the farmer, too. Now we have schoolchildren with raisins.        We have the farmer having more money.  Sounds like a pretty good program.  Of course, you have taken some raisins. But what I don't see is how either the farmer or the schoolchildren are any the worse off.  And if they're no worse off, what compensation are these farmers entitled to? Of course, free riders could become yet better off.  They could charge at the higher price that the program creates, $800.  But, after all, that isn't the issue because you have to have, as a rule, no free riders.  And once you admit that as a rule, everyone, including perhaps these plaintiffs, are better off than none at all. Now, that's a very simple argument.        It's what I understand to be the economics of the Brannan Plan, the FDR, the 1949, et cetera.  And yet, we've had endless cases, complexities, opinions, and fines. And -- and so, therefore, I'm probably wrong with my Alderson Reporting Company simple argument. Of course, I doubt that I'm wrong, but nonetheless, I want you to explain what's wrong with it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If you want to say it's not a taking --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. -- Mr. Kneedler, if -- I largely agree with what the Chief Justice said. I mean, just the way I think about this program is that this does seem a weird historical anomaly. And all -- am I right that all the rest of these agricultural programs are done differently, such that saying that this was a taking would not affect other agricultural programs? And -- and also, are there any other programs out there -- forget agricultural Alderson Reporting Company programs -- but are there any other programs out there that we should be concerned about if we were to think about this as a taking?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I -- I'm sorry.  But you said that there were eight or ten other programs that, you said, they have --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How long --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Any --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- have they not been actively utilized?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And -- and what if --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And -- and Mr. Kneedler, what of the nonagricultural programs?  Are there regulatory programs where the government says, produce something that is characterizable as property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Right.  But we -- we know about that one.  Anything else out there? I mean, tell me what the -- the realm of regulatory programs is that we ought to be concerned about if we were to say something like the production of something -- the production of stuff that somebody claims a property interest in is a taking.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Or I -- I -- look --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I guess the government can prohibit the -- the introduction of harmful pesticides into interstate commerce.  I'm not sure it can prohibit the introduction of raisins. I mean, that's a -- you know, dangerous raisins. (Laughter.) Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I -- I -- I can understand imposing that condition on Monsanto, and that would not be an unconstitutional condition.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems to me it is when you impose it on raisins.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: This is not --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but what you take from Monsanto, and look at your brief on page 32 when you cite Monsanto, you say that producers who are dissatisfied with the reserve regulations may plant different crops. That's a pretty audacious statement. If you don't like our regulations, do something else.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What, you mean -- you mean wine?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But normally --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- normally what we say, if you don't like regulations, you can challenge them in court to see if they comply with the Constitution.  The answer -- I mean, if the answer is always you can do something else, it would seem we should -- we'll never have these kinds of cases.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All that's true --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It seems --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- but they brought their claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It seems to me what your argument --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  Justice Kennedy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It seems to me what your argument is saying, is even if it's a taking, it's okay. It will be okay.  Everything will work out.  That's what I get from your argument.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So if you don't like -- we're going to say the Pledge of Allegiance in public schools, and we're going to make everybody stand. And if you don't like it, go to a different school.  I don't understand why that's not the same analysis here. We may be taking -- you know, this may be a taking of your raisins or not, but if -- and if you don't like it, grow something else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Where -- where -- whereas, you say that introducing raisins into interstate commerce is a government benefit, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No.  No, not the regulatory.  You're saying the activity, which is subjected to this taking, is the introduction of raisins in interstate commerce.  And you say that is something that the benign government can give or withhold.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Really?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Mr. McConnell was asked a number of questions about the Leonard case.  But I take it that you don't think that the Leonard case has a very important bearing on this case because you cite it one time in your brief, it's a passing reference, on the issue of fungible goods.  Am I correct there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You don't think -- you didn't propose -- you didn't suggest to us that this case is just another version of Leonard and, therefore, we should affirm based on Leonard.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So -- so put all --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Put all the regulatory aspects of the program aside for a moment, and just say this were a much simpler program, and it said -- the government says to the raisin industry, you know, we could tax you, and say you have to deliver 2 percent of your net profits, we're not going to do that, we're just going to take 2 percent of your raisins. Would that be constitutional?        Would that be a taking?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But you said you don't think of this case in that way.  And why don't you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.  But we -- we don't usually allow committees of producers who are called the government to impose taxes, do we?  I mean, that's usually done by Congress.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And this essentially is done by some committee.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It may well be.  So -- so they can impose taxes, you're saying.  This is just like a tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Whatever a majority of producers agree to, I have to be bound by?  I mean, these people disagree.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm not saying the disagreement converts it into a taking.  I'm just saying that it doesn't -- it doesn't carry much water to say that this is a program adopted by -- by producers.  If 51 percent of the producers want to do it, there's 49 that don't want to do it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Central planning was thought to work very well in 1937, and Russia tried it for a long time.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but what if -- I mean, you've -- you've made the point several times that the government sells these raisins for the benefit of the producers, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, what if the producers, some of them, think they can do a better job of selling them?  They can get a better price because they're better producers, they're better marketers, they have export contacts that others don't.  I --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but that's not Alderson Reporting Company usually -- when you're talking about that type of regulation, I understand that, you know, the raisins have to be so big or you can't call them raisins, and they've -- you've got to have safety inspections and all.  But you've been presenting this as the reason this is a good program is because we sell the raisins, and then we give some of what's left to the -- to the producers.  I don't think that's a very common approach to market regulation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Suppose the same sort of program were carried out with respect to real property. Would you -- would you provide the same answers? Suppose that property owners, owners of real property in a particular area, think that the value of their property would be increased if they all surrendered a certain amount of that property to the government for the purpose of producing a -- creating a park or for some other reason. And so they -- they get the municipality to -- to set up this program, and one of them objects to surrendering this part of that person -- of his or her land. Would -- would that not be a taking?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, why -- why would it be -- I thought you said you're not arguing that there's a difference between real property and personal property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Kneedler, what's the statute of limitations on a takings claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Has there been any reserves created in the last six years?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Kneedler, explain to me why -- why -- why the market for raisins is inelastic. You mean people won't buy more raisins if they're cheaper? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Really?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Kneedler, you don't have to convince us that this is a sensible program for you to prevail, do you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I mean, we could think that this is a ridiculous program; isn't that right? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: We could think that this is a ridiculous program.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Kneedler, I'd like to get you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It doesn't help your case that it's ridiculous, though.  You -- you acknowledge that. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It isn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But this is a serious point, actually, because the ridiculousness or sensibleness of a program is really not for us to decide.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. -- Mr. Kneedler, you were asked this before, but your answer wasn't clear. Marketing orders of this sort that have a reserve pool, you said there were 8 or 10.  Have any others been operative as this one has been?  It was started in '49 and how many years -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Those -- is the government selling the reserve?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How many -- oh, go ahead.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How many -- how many of these programs are there?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Marketing orders.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I mean, I'm trying to put the 8 to 10 in -- in relation to -- to how many.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. McConnell, you have five minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Happens with trustees all the time, to the extent that we've eschewed taking formal titles as meaningful with respect to actual control or actual benefit.  We -- trustees take title and -- but it's not for their benefit.  It's for the benefit of their beneficiary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Oh, but in a form, yes. It's directed to sell the reserve raisins at the best price it can get, given the limitations on the free market.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You -- you have only four minutes in rebuttal.  You had some other points? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That last -- what -- why isn't it for them to make that argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The argument, you know, that it's -- you're better off, et cetera.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Did they waive it?  I mean, what's -- what's -- what's the answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But -- can they argue that -- the fact that all the raisin producers are better off because of this program, including you, but no free riders, that's what's the compensation.  Can they at least argue that?  Or have they conceded that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The exporters.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. McConnell, could I take you back to the very first thing that you said in this argument?  Because you said typically, the handler doesn't take the product and the handler doesn't pay for the product, and you would think that the Hornes here would only have a takings claim, assuming that they do have a takings claim, for the raisins that they produced and not for the raisins that other people produced.  But you said that that's not correct in this case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. McConnell, this is probably neither here nor there, but what has the impact of the drought been on the raisin producers? Do you know?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Very carefully guarded response. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you. I'm glad I asked.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
